	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	1
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Historical data and full-year 2014 estimates as reported by Gartner Dataquest in its fourth quarter 2014 report.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	2
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Historical data are based on figures as included in the Gartner Dataquest fourth quarter 2014 report. Where appropriate, the estimates as included in the Gartner Dataquest
	reports in prior years have been updated based on this fourth quarter 2014 report.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	For the year 2014, the latest indications of
	independent market analysts show a decrease in total lithography equipment shipped to the market of 4.5 percent in unit volume and an increase of 12.6 percent in value. In 2014 ASML sold 136 systems, compared to 157 in 2013. However, our net system
	sales also increased 6.3 percent (mainly NXE:3300B) in 2014 compared to 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<U>
	Business Strategy
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	General
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The long-term growth of the semiconductor industry
	is based on the principle that the power, cost and time required for every computation on a digital electronic device can be reduced by shrinking the size of transistors on chips. In 2014, chip makers routinely produced electronic chip features with
	geometries of 20 nm, compared to typical geometries of 10,000 nm in the early 1970s, resulting in an increase in the number of transistors on leading chips from several thousand to over two billion. This trend was first observed by Intel co-founder
	Gordon Moore in 1965, and is referred to as &#147;Moore&#146;s Law&#148;. Moore&#146;s Law is reflected in ever smaller, cheaper, more powerful and energy-efficient semiconductors. Smaller geometries allow for much lower electrical currents to
	operate the chip. This has helped to stabilize the world&#146;s energy consumption despite the proliferation of affordable computing. Using advanced semiconductors in industrial and consumer products often provides economic benefits,
	user-friendliness and increased safety. The technology revolution powered by the semiconductor industry has brought many advantages: not only can information be more widely disseminated than ever before, affordable chip intelligence has also enabled
	industry and service sectors to create and distribute products and ideas at lightning speed.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="35%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="31%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	ASML ANNUAL REPORT 2014
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	22
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<A NAME="eolPage31"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D737660D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Our vision is that ASML makes possible affordable microelectronics that improve the quality of life. What we do to
	realize our vision is to invent, develop and manufacture high-tech lithography, metrology and software solutions for the semiconductor industry that provide the &#147;patterning&#148; of chips and hence enable the creation of smarter, smaller and
	more energy-efficient chips. We implement our vision and mission by executing our business strategy which consists of three elements:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	1. Providing
	leading technology and cost-effective products and services for patterning of semiconductor devices;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	2. Strong relationships with customers as well as
	suppliers and peers to drive the patterning eco-system; and
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	3. Develop our people and organization to support our growing business and industry.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	When executed, this strategy results in the delivery of lithography systems which enable customers to produce chips at lower costs and with higher value
	per product. The superior value of ownership offered to customers as a result of our strategy also drives our own financial performance, aligning the interests of ASML and our customers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Leading Technology and Cost Effective Products
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Our customers need lithography scanners that continuously
	improve performance in three areas: imaging, throughput and overlay. Because the image of the electronic chip circuit must be extremely small (in 2014 chip makers routinely produced electronic chip features with geometries of 20 nm), the system must
	be able to image billions of these features every second and it must be able to do that with extreme precision of just a few nm (one nm is four silicon atoms). To realize and improve system performance for our customers on all three mentioned areas
	above, ASML needs to deliver the right technology at the right time to meet long-term roadmaps of our customers which often extend many years into the future and are driven primarily by a desire to maintain Moore&#146;s Law. Therefore, ASML is
	committed to significant long-term investments in R&amp;D.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	In order to meet the imaging, throughput and overlay demands of our customers, we have
	focused our R&amp;D investments on three core programs: EUV, DUV and holistic lithography solutions. In 2014, our R&amp;D costs (net of credits) amounted to EUR 1,074.1&nbsp;million (2013: EUR 882.0 million; 2012: EUR 589.2 million). A significant
	part of our R&amp;D-budget has been used for R&amp;D jointly developed with our suppliers and technology partners. In addition, as part of the CCIP, Participating Customers are funding development costs relating to lithography projects and in 2014,
	we recognized other income in relation to the contributions made by certain Participating Customers of EUR 81.0&nbsp;million (2013: EUR 64.4 million; 2012: nil) in connection with the CCIP.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	For further details on our product development and products, see Item&nbsp;4.B. &#147;Business Overview &#150; Product Development and Products&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Strong Relations with Customers, Suppliers and Peers
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Ensuring customers are served with the right products at
	the right time and supported by excellent service, is key to our commitment to a long-term relationship. With high-valued products, customers expect high-quality support customized to their specific requirements. This support includes service
	engineers, equipped with the latest technical information, to ensure the highest level of system performance, as well as applications specialists who support optimal system processing and new product implementation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	ASML aims to deliver lithography systems with the lowest cost of ownership.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Customer satisfaction is a critical objective of ASML. We have account teams that are specifically dedicated to customer satisfaction throughout the lifecycle of our products.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Through 2014, all of the top 10 chipmakers worldwide, in terms of semiconductor capital expenditure, were our customers. We also have a significant share of
	customers outside the top 10. We strive for continued business growth with all our customers. We expect that customer concentration might increase because of continuing consolidation in the semiconductor manufacturing industry.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	See Item&nbsp;3.D. &#147;Risk Factors &#150; Risks Related to ASML &#150; A High Percentage of Net Sales Is Derived from a Few Customers&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	In 2014, our satisfaction ratings by customers surpassed every lithography competitor. According to VLSI Research, ASML ranks second among the large semiconductor
	industry equipment suppliers and first among lithography competitors. Our performance has consistently been strong: for twelve years in a row we have both ranked among the top 5 semiconductor industry suppliers and our ranking surpassed that of any
	of our lithography competitors.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Another significant pillar in our business strategy is close relations with suppliers. They provide us with components,
	modules and sub-systems according to our specifications.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="35%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="31%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	ASML ANNUAL REPORT 2014
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	23
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<A NAME="eolPage32"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D737660D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Develop our People and Organization to Support our Growing Business and Industry
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The nature of our R&amp;D intensive business depends on a highly skilled work force and efficient organization that boosts inspiration and engagement.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	We therefore take training and development very seriously, of our payroll and non-payroll employees alike. Long-term employability through continuous development
	is important for the well-being of our employees, for ASML and for society.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	As the expectations of our customers continue to increase, leading to more
	complex products and stakeholder interactions, it is essential we continuously look for efficiencies. We therefore continue to improve our organization in view of the volatility of the semiconductor industry, the long-term growth of our business,
	and the engagement of our employees.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The three elements which make up our business strategy are complemented with responsible behavior as prerequisite
	in executing this strategy. The next section summarizes CR within our company.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Corporate Responsibility
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	More than delivering strong financial performance, we want to create long-term value for our stakeholders and for society as a whole. To this end, we identify and
	manage non-financial developments that are material to our business and performance. Investing in these non-financial or CR themes is a prerequisite for our long-term business continuity and success. We believe that we can significantly enhance our
	long-term performance if we successfully manage the risks associated with these developments and seize the opportunities they offer.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	In 2014, we moved
	CR higher on our business agenda. We have further developed our new CR strategy and policy that formulates our ambitions for the period 2015-2020. It sets out the main non-financial, social and environmental impact areas and most significant
	indicators we will use to measure our progress. We believe this is an important step towards further aligning our CR objectives with our business strategy and a significant step towards integrating financial and non-financial reporting.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	To celebrate our company&#146;s 30th anniversary on April&nbsp;1, 2014 we launched &#145;30 for Change&#146;, a global initiative with the ASML Foundation to
	support 29 projects reflecting ASML&#146;s diversity and empowering underprivileged youth through education. Our employees worldwide worked together in submitting, selecting and raising funds for the charity projects. These projects strengthen our
	bonds with the community but at the same time contribute to employee involvement and our need to have access to the largest possible pool of technical talent.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The 2014 CR Report describes our CR strategy, achievements and contributions to sustainable business practices. The 2014 CR Report can be found on our Website. Information on ASML&#146;s Website is not incorporated
	into, and does not form a part of, this Annual Report.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<U>
	Profitability
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Our long term business model target requires us to achieve annual income from operations as percentage of net sales of greater than 30 percent. However in exceptional circumstances, as evidenced by the financial
	and economic crisis in 2008-2009, we could see periods with income from operations that are substantially below our minimum target level.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:2PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	1
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	As a percentage of net sales.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	2
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Our systems backlog and net bookings include sales orders for which written authorizations have been accepted and shipment and/or revenue recognition is expected within 12
	months. As of 2014 we also include EUV in our backlog starting with our NXE:3350B systems. As a result, two NXE:3350B systems are now included in our systems backlog and net bookings. Before 2014, our systems backlog and net bookings include only
	sales orders for which written authorizations have been accepted and system shipment and revenue recognition dates within the following 12 months have been assigned. This change has no impact on the comparative figures.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	3
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Included in the total number of immersion systems recognized in 2014 are 48 units of our most advanced immersion technology NXT:1970Ci systems (2013: 4 and 2012: nil).
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<U>
	Backlog
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	We started 2014 with a
	systems backlog of 56 systems. In 2014, we booked orders for 157 systems, and recognized sales for 136 systems (including 5 NXE:3300B systems, which were not included in backlog). This resulted in a systems backlog of 82 as of December&nbsp;31,
	2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2014, our systems backlog was valued at EUR 2,772.4&nbsp;million and includes 82 systems with an ASP of EUR 33.8 million.
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2013, the systems backlog was valued at EUR 1,953.3&nbsp;million and included 56 systems with an ASP of EUR 34.9 million. The ASP of our systems backlog mainly decreased in 2014 compared to 2013 as a result of a shift in the
	mix towards KrF, partly offset by the inclusion of two NXE:3350B systems.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	For discussion on the main key performance indicators indicated above, see
	Item&nbsp;5.A. &#147;Operating Results&#148; and Item&nbsp;5.B. &#147;Liquidity and Capital Resources&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

	ASML ANNUAL REPORT 2014
</FONT>
</TD>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D737660D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D737660D20F_HTM_TOC737660_17">
</A>
	A. Operating Results
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<U>
	Critical Accounting Policies Using Significant Estimates
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Our discussion and analysis of our financial
	condition and results of operations are based upon our Financial Statements, which have been prepared in conformity with US GAAP. The preparation of our Financial Statements requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported
	amounts of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities on the balance sheet dates, and the reported amounts of net sales and costs during the reported periods. Actual results could differ from those estimates. We
	evaluate our estimates continuously and we base our estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that we believe to be reasonable under the circumstances. Actual results may differ from these estimates if the assumptions prove
	incorrect. To the extent there are material differences between actual results and these estimates, our future results could be materially and adversely affected. We believe that the accounting policies described below require us to make significant
	judgments and estimates in the preparation of our Financial Statements. Our most critical accounting estimates include:
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Net Sales and Gross Profit

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The following table shows a summary of sales data, units sold, gross profit and ASP data for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:16PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">

</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="RIGHT">

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:2PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Net sales increased by EUR
	611.0&nbsp;million, or 11.6 percent, to EUR 5,856.3&nbsp;million in 2014 from EUR 5,245.3&nbsp;million in 2013, mainly driven by the increase in net service and field option sales of EUR 361.3&nbsp;million, or 28.9 percent to EUR
	1,613.5&nbsp;million in 2014 from EUR 1,252.2&nbsp;million in 2013. The increase in net service and field option sales is mainly caused by:
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The full-year effect of Cymer in 2014, whereas 2013 only includes Cymer for seven months; and
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Holistic Lithography increased through the sales of integrated metrology and feedback loop technology.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The increase in net system sales of EUR 249.7&nbsp;million, or 6.3 percent, to EUR 4,242.8&nbsp;million in 2014 from EUR 3,993.1&nbsp;million in 2013 is caused by
	higher NXE:3300B system sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The increase of the ASP of our systems sold can mainly be explained by the ASP of our new systems sold which increased
	to EUR 35.6&nbsp;million in 2014 from EUR 27.4&nbsp;million in 2013, which was the result of a shift in the mix of systems sold towards more high-end system types (NXE:3300B and NXT:1970Ci systems) in 2014 compared to 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Gross profit increased by EUR 419.2&nbsp;million, or 19.3 percent, to EUR 2,596.4&nbsp;million in 2014 from EUR 2,177.2&nbsp;million in 2013. The increase in gross
	profit was mainly driven by:
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The full-year effect of Cymer in 2014, whereas 2013 only includes Cymer for seven months;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Holistic Lithography increased through the sales of integrated metrology and feedback loop technology; and
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	2014 Includes lower one-off purchase price accounting adjustments related to Cymer.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Gross profit as a percentage of net sales increased from 41.5 percent in 2013 to 44.3 percent in 2014, for the same reasons as gross profit increased, partly offset by higher EUV sales (which currently do not
	contribute to gross profit).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:24PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Other Income
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Other
	income consists of contributions for R&amp;D programs under the NRE funding arrangements from certain Participating Customers in the CCIP and amounted to EUR 81.0&nbsp;million for 2014 (2013: EUR 64.4 million).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:24PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Research and Development Costs
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	R&amp;D costs (net of
	credits and excluding contributions under the NRE Funding Agreements from certain Participating Customers in the CCIP) increased by EUR 192.1&nbsp;million, or 21.8 percent, to EUR 1,074.1&nbsp;million in 2014 from EUR 882.0&nbsp;million in 2013.
	R&amp;D costs increased mainly due to the acceleration of certain R&amp;D programs, primarily EUV and next-generation immersion.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:24PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Selling, General
	and Administrative Costs
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	SG&amp;A costs increased by EUR 9.4&nbsp;million, or 3.0 percent, to EUR 321.1&nbsp;million in 2014, from EUR
	311.7&nbsp;million in 2013. This increase was mainly driven by the full-year effect of Cymer in 2014, whereas 2013 only includes Cymer for seven months.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:24PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Interest and Other, Net
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Interest and other, net decreased
	by EUR 15.8&nbsp;million in 2014 compared to 2013. In 2013 interest and other, net included a loss on the partial extinguishment of our EUR 600&nbsp;million 5.75 percent senior notes due 2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="35%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="31%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	ASML ANNUAL REPORT 2014
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	27
</FONT>
</TD>

<A NAME="eolPage36"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D737660D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Income Taxes
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The effective tax rate increased to 6.0 percent of income before income taxes in 2014 compared to 0.8 percent in 2013. In 2014 the tax rate was favorably impacted
	by settling agreements entered into by ASML Netherlands B.V. and Cymer LLC., prior to our acquisition of Cymer in 2013, at different tax rates. In 2013, we recognized a gain as a result of the accounting for business combinations Cymer. This gain is
	not recognized for tax purposes and was, apart from the R&amp;D tax incentives, the major driver for the change in the effective tax rate in 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:24PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Net Income
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Net income in 2014 amounted to EUR
	1,196.6&nbsp;million, or 20.4 percent of net sales, representing EUR 2.74 basic net income per ordinary share, compared with net income in 2013 of EUR 1,015.5&nbsp;million, or 19.4 percent of net sales, representing EUR 2.36 basic net income per
	ordinary share.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_11"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:24PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">

</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Net income
</FONT>

<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	28
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:2PX SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:2PX SOLID #000000">

	&nbsp;
</TD>

</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Net sales increased by EUR 513.8&nbsp;million, or 10.9 percent, to EUR 5,245.3&nbsp;million in 2013 from EUR 4,731.5&nbsp;million
	in 2012, mainly driven by the increase in net service and field option sales of EUR 322.3&nbsp;million, or 34.7 percent to EUR 1,252.2&nbsp;million in 2013 from EUR 929.9&nbsp;million in 2012. The increase in net service and field option sales was
	mainly caused by the expansion of Holistic Lithography through increased sales of integrated metrology and feedback loop technology and by OnPulse revenues as a result of the acquisition of Cymer.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The increase in net system sales of EUR 191.5&nbsp;million, or 5.0 percent, to EUR 3,993.1&nbsp;million in 2013 from EUR 3,801.6&nbsp;million in 2012 was mainly
	caused by an increased ASP which more than offset the lower amount of systems sold.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The increase of the ASP of our systems sold was mainly explained by
	the ASP of our new systems sold which increased to EUR 27.4&nbsp;million in 2013 from EUR 24.8&nbsp;million in 2012, which was the result of a shift in the mix of systems sold towards more high-end system types, NXT:1960Bi and NXT:1970Ci and
	including one NXE:3300B.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Through 2013, all of the top 10 chipmakers worldwide, in terms of semiconductor capital expenditure, were our customers. In
	2013, recognized sales to our largest customer accounted for EUR 2,058.6&nbsp;million, or 39.2 percent of our net sales. In 2012, recognized sales to our largest customer accounted for EUR 1,236.1&nbsp;million, or 26.1 percent of our net sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Gross profit increased by EUR 172.0&nbsp;million to EUR 2,177.2&nbsp;million or 41.5 percent of net sales in 2013 from EUR 2,005.2&nbsp;million or 42.4
	percent of net sales in 2012. Higher gross profit was mainly driven by the increased net system sales. Gross profit as a percentage of net sales in 2013 decreased compared to 2012, mainly due to a 1.6 percent impact from non-cash purchase price
	accounting adjustments related to the Cymer acquisition.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Other Income
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Other income consisted of contributions for R&amp;D programs under the NRE funding arrangements from Participating Customers in the CCIP and amounted to EUR 64.4&nbsp;million for 2013 (2012: nil).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Research and Development Costs
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	R&amp;D costs (net of
	credits and excluding contributions under the NRE funding agreements from Participating Customers in the CCIP) increased by EUR 292.9&nbsp;million, or 49.7 percent, to EUR 882.0&nbsp;million in 2013 from EUR 589.1&nbsp;million in 2012. R&amp;D
	spending mainly increased due the additional investments in EUV source development as a result of the acquisition of Cymer and further investments in our other strategic programs (Immersion and holistic lithography).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Selling, General and Administrative Costs
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	SG&amp;A costs
	increased by EUR 52.4&nbsp;million, or 20.2 percent, to EUR 311.7&nbsp;million in 2013, from EUR 259.3&nbsp;million in 2012. The increase was mainly driven by the acquisition and subsequent integration of Cymer and incurred restructuring expenses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Interest and Other, Net
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Interest and other, net
	increased by EUR 18.2&nbsp;million to EUR 24.4&nbsp;million expense in 2013 from EUR 6.2&nbsp;million expense in 2012. This increase was mainly explained by the loss on the partial extinguishment of our EUR 600&nbsp;million 5.75 percent senior notes
	due 2017 and a lower yield generated on our cash and cash equivalents and short -term investments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

<A NAME="eolPage38"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D737660D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Income Taxes
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The effective tax rate increased to 0.8 percent of income before income taxes in 2013 compared to 0.4 percent in 2012. In 2013, the effective tax rate was impacted
	by the settlement of the favorable pre-existing relationships between Cymer and ASML. This settlement gain was not recognized for tax purposes and was, apart from the R&amp;D tax incentives, the major driver for the change in the effective tax rate
	in 2013. In 2012, the effective tax rate was amongst others impacted by a one-time tax benefit resulting from successful conclusion of tax audits. The movement in the liability for unrecognized tax benefits in 2013 was considered to be limited
	compared to 2012.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Net Income
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Net income in 2013
	amounted to EUR 1,015.5&nbsp;million, or 19.4 percent of net sales, representing EUR 2.36 basic net income per ordinary share, compared with net income in 2012 of EUR 1,146.3&nbsp;million, or 24.2 percent of net sales, representing EUR 2.70 basic
	net income per ordinary share.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<U>
	Foreign Exchange Management
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	See Item&nbsp;3.D. &#147;Risk Factors &#150; Fluctuations in Foreign Exchange Rates Could Harm Our Results of Operations&#148;, Item&nbsp;11 &#147;Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk&#148;,
	Note 1 and Note 4 to our Financial Statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D737660D20F_HTM_TOC737660_18">
</A>
	B. Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Our cash and cash equivalents increased to EUR 2,419.5&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 from EUR 2,330.7&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2013 and our
	short-term investments decreased to EUR 334.9&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 from EUR 679.9&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	We
	generated net cash from operating activities of EUR 1,025.2&nbsp;million, EUR 1,054.2&nbsp;million and EUR 703.5&nbsp;million in 2014, 2013 and 2012, respectively. Lower net cash provided by operating activities in 2014 compared to 2013 relates to
	increased working capital, which is mainly due to a decrease in accounts payable. Higher net cash provided by operating activities in 2013 compared to 2012 related to increased sales levels and decreased our working capital, mainly due to an
	increase in accounts payable.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	We used EUR 16.2&nbsp;million for investing activities in 2014, EUR 368.4&nbsp;million in 2013 and EUR
	1,119.8&nbsp;million in 2012. In 2014, our investing activities mainly related to the purchase of property, plant and equipment of EUR 358.3&nbsp;million, mainly for the construction of our EUV production facilities in Veldhoven, the Netherlands.
	This was offset by the decrease of short-term investments, mainly in Dutch Treasury Certificates and deposits with the Dutch government, of EUR 345.0 million. In 2013, our investing activities mainly related to the cash consideration paid for the
	acquisition of Cymer of EUR 443.7&nbsp;million and the purchase of property, plant and equipment of EUR 210.8&nbsp;million, mainly related to further expansion of our EUV production facilities. This was to a large extent offset by the decrease of
	short-term investments, mainly in Dutch Treasury Certificates and deposits with the Dutch government, of EUR 290.2 million. In 2012, our investing activities primarily related to our short-term investments in Dutch Treasury Certificates and deposits
	with the Dutch government of EUR 930.0&nbsp;million and purchases of property, plant and equipment of EUR 171.9 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Net cash used in financing
	activities was EUR 928.4&nbsp;million in 2014, EUR 113.1&nbsp;million in 2013, and EUR 545.6&nbsp;million in 2012. In 2014, net cash used in financing activities included a cash outflow of EUR 700.0&nbsp;million for our regular share buyback program
	and our annual dividend payment of EUR 268.0&nbsp;million, slightly offset by EUR 39.7&nbsp;million net proceeds from issuance of shares in connection with the exercise and purchase of employee stock and stock options. In 2013, net cash used in
	financing activities included the net cash proceeds of EUR 740.4&nbsp;million from our notes offering and net cash proceeds of EUR 31.8&nbsp;million from the issuance of shares in connection with the exercise and purchase of employee stock options,
	mainly offset by net cash outflows of EUR 368.3&nbsp;million for our notes tender offer and unwinding of related interest rate swaps, EUR 300.0&nbsp;million for our regular share buyback program and EUR 216.1&nbsp;million for our annual dividend
	payment. In 2012, net cash used in financing activities included the net cash outflow of EUR 3,728.3&nbsp;million for the synthetic share buyback, EUR 535.4&nbsp;million for our regular share buyback programs and EUR 188.9&nbsp;million for our
	annual dividend payment, to a large extent offset by the proceeds of EUR 3,853.9&nbsp;million from issuance of shares under the CCIP and EUR 53.8&nbsp;million net proceeds from issuance of shares in connection with the exercise and purchase of
	employee stock options.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Our principal sources of liquidity consist of cash flows from operations, cash and cash equivalents as of December&nbsp;31,
	2014 of EUR 2,419.5&nbsp;million, short-term investments as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 of EUR 334.9&nbsp;million and available credit facilities as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 of EUR 700.0 million. In addition, we may from time to time raise additional
	capital in debt and equity markets. Our goal is to remain an investment grade rated company and maintain a capital structure that supports this.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

<A NAME="eolPage39"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D737660D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	We invest our cash and cash equivalents and short-term investments in short-term deposits with financial institutions
	that have good credit ratings and with the Dutch government, in Dutch Treasury Certificates and in AAAm-rated money market funds that invest in high-rated short-term debt securities of financial institutions and governments. Our investments are
	denominated in euros.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Our available credit facility consists of a EUR 700.0&nbsp;million committed revolving credit facility from a group of banks that
	will mature in 2018. The credit facility contains a restrictive covenant that requires us to maintain a minimum committed capital to net total assets ratio of 40.0 percent calculated in accordance with contractually agreed definitions. At the end of
	2014, we were in compliance with the covenant. Outstanding amounts under this credit facility will bear interest at EURIBOR or LIBOR plus a margin that depends on our liquidity position. No amounts were outstanding under the credit facility as of
	December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	We have repayment obligations in 2017, amounting to EUR 238.2&nbsp;million and in 2023, amounting to EUR 750.0&nbsp;million,
	both relating to our Eurobonds.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	ASML seeks to ensure that cash generated from operations, together with the liquidity provided by existing cash and
	cash equivalents and short-term investments and its borrowing capability, will be sufficient to satisfy its liquidity requirements throughout every phase of the industry cycles.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Our liquidity needs are affected by many factors, some of which are based on the normal on-going operations of the business, and others that relate to the uncertainties of the global economy and the semiconductor
	industry. Although our cash requirements fluctuate based on the timing and extent of these factors, we believe that cash generated from operations, together with the liquidity provided by existing cash and cash equivalents and short-term investments
	and our borrowing capability are sufficient to satisfy our current requirements, including our expected capital expenditures in 2015. We intend to return cash to our shareholders on a regular basis in the form of dividend payments and, subject to
	our actual and anticipated liquidity requirements and other relevant factors, share buybacks or capital repayment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	See Notes 4, 5, 15, 16, 26 and 27 to
	our Financial Statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D737660D20F_HTM_TOC737660_19">
</A>
	C. Research and Development, Patents and Licenses, etc.
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<U>
	Research and Development
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	See Item&nbsp;4.B. &#147;Business
	Overview &#150; Research and Development&#148; and Item&nbsp;5.A. &#147;Operating Results &#150; Results of Operations&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<U>
	Intellectual Property
	Matters
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	See Item&nbsp;3.D. &#147;Risk Factors &#150; Failure to Adequately Protect the Intellectual Property Rights Upon Which We depend Could Harm
	Our Business&#148; and &#147;Risk Factors &#150; Defending Against Intellectual Property Claims by Others Could Harm Our Business&#148; and Item&nbsp;4.B. &#147;Business Overview &#150; Intellectual Property&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D737660D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D737660D20F_HTM_TOC737660_20">
</A>
	D. Trend Information
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	In EUV, we have made significant progress and we have met the 500-wafer-per-day target that our customers set for us in 2014 as we have now demonstrated these productivity levels at multiple customers over multiple
	days. We also demonstrated source power at 100 Watts with 96 percent die yield, a key factor to get to the productivity levels that our customers need for volume production. Our 2015 productivity target remains at 1,000 wafers per day and
	importantly for our customers and for our EUV program, we received the first 2 orders for our fourth-generation NXE:3350B systems, the first of which is planned for shipment mid-year 2015. In addition, two NXE:3300B systems already delivered will be
	upgraded to NXE:3350B performance.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Looking ahead to the first half of 2015 for DUV, we expect both our sales to the Memory segment and our service and
	field option business to continue to be strong and sales to the logic segment to increase from the second half year of 2014 to the first half year of 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The following table sets forth our systems backlog as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	1
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Our systems backlog and net bookings include sales orders for which written authorizations have been accepted and shipment and/or revenue recognition is expected within 12
	months. As of 2014 we also include EUV in our backlog starting with our NXE:3350B systems. As a result, two NXE:3350B systems are now included in our systems backlog and net bookings. Before 2014, our systems backlog and net bookings include only
	sales orders for which written authorizations have been accepted and system shipment and revenue recognition dates within the following 12 months have been assigned. This change has no impact on the comparative figures.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Historically, orders have been subject to cancellation or delay by the customer. Due to possible customer changes in delivery schedules and to cancellation of
	orders, our systems backlog at any particular date is not necessarily indicative of actual sales for any succeeding period.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	For the first quarter of
	2015, we expect net sales of around EUR 1.6 billion, a gross margin of around 47 percent, R&amp;D costs of about EUR 260&nbsp;million, other income of about EUR 20&nbsp;million, which consists of contributions from participants of the CCIP and
	SG&amp;A costs of about EUR 83 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	On January&nbsp;21, 2015 we announced a new share buyback program, to be executed within the 2015-2016
	timeframe. As part of this program, we intend to purchase up to EUR 750&nbsp;million of shares which we intend to cancel upon repurchase. In addition, we intend to purchase as part of this program up to 3.3&nbsp;million shares to cover employee
	stock and stock option plans. This buyback program will start on January&nbsp;22, 2015, and at current share price these intended repurchases represent a total value of approximately EUR 1 billion.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The trends discussed in this Item&nbsp;5.D. &#147;Trend information&#148; are subject to risks and uncertainties. See &#147;Part I &#150; Special Note Regarding
	Forward Looking Statements&#148; and item 3.D. &#147;Risk Factors&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D737660D20F_HTM_TOC737660_21">
</A>
	E. Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	We have various contractual obligations, some of which are required to be recognized as liabilities in our Financial Statements, including long- and
	short-term debt. Other contractual obligations, namely operating lease commitments, purchase obligations and guarantees, are generally not required to be recognized as liabilities on our balance sheet but are required to be disclosed.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Long-term debt obligations mainly relate to interest payments and principal amounts of our Eurobonds. See Note 15 to our Financial Statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Operating lease obligations include leases of equipment and facilities. Lease payments recognized as an expense were EUR 43.9&nbsp;million, EUR 42.0&nbsp;million and EUR 41.6&nbsp;million for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, 2013 and 2012, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Several operating leases for our buildings contain purchase options, exercisable at the end of the
	lease, and in some cases, during the term of the lease. The amounts to be paid if ASML should exercise these purchase options at the end of the lease as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 can be summarized as follows:

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Purchase obligations include purchase commitments with suppliers in the ordinary course of business. ASML expects that it will
	honor these purchase obligations to fulfill future sales, in line with the timing of those future sales. The general terms and conditions of the agreements relating to the major part of our purchase commitments as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 contain
	clauses that enable us to delay or cancel delivery of ordered goods and services up to the dates specified in the corresponding purchase contracts. These terms and conditions that we typically agree with our supply chain partners gives us additional
	flexibility to adapt our purchase obligations to our requirements in light of the inherent cyclicality of the industry in which we operate. We establish a provision for cancellation costs when it is probable that the liability has been incurred and
	the amount of cancellation fees is reasonably estimable.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D737660D20F_HTM_TOC737660_23">
</A>
	G. Safe Harbor
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	See Part I &#147;Special Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	1969
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	2018&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>

</EFX_NAME_AND_TITLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:2PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	1
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Member of the Audit Committee.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	2
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Member of the Selection and Nomination Committee.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	3
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Member of the Technology and Strategy Committee.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	4
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Member of the Remuneration Committee
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	5
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Mr.&nbsp;Fr&ouml;hlich is to retire by rotation at the 2015 AGM. See below discussion of nominees for appointment to the Supervisory Board at the 2015 AGM.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Mr.&nbsp;Bilous retired from the Supervisory Board per the 2014 AGM. Mr.&nbsp;Fr&ouml;hlich retired by rotation and was reappointed for a
	period of one year in line with the Supervisory Board&#146;s rotation schedule. At the 2014 AGM Mr.&nbsp;Stork was appointed as member of the Supervisory Board for a period of four years.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	With great sadness, the Supervisory Board remembers the late Ms.&nbsp;Van den Burg, member of our Supervisory Board and member of our Selection and Nomination Committee and Remuneration Committee, who passed away
	on September&nbsp;28, 2014. Over the past nine years, Ms.&nbsp;Van den Burg was an engaged and knowledgeable member of our Supervisory Board. The Supervisory Board is grateful for the time she dedicated to ASML.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The Works Council has an enhanced right to make recommendations for nomination of one-third of the members of the Supervisory Board, which recommendations may be
	rejected by the Supervisory Board in limited circumstances. See Item&nbsp;6.C. &#147;Board Practices &#151; Supervisory Board&#148;. At the Annual General Meeting of Shareholders held in 2009, Ms.&nbsp;Van der Meer Mohr was appointed pursuant to
	this recommendation right, and at the 2013 AGM she was reappointed in accordance with this recommendation right. At the 2014 AGM, Mr.&nbsp;Stork was appointed pursuant to this recommendation right. The appointment of Ms.&nbsp;Van den Burg&#146;s
	successor at the 2015 AGM will be based on this enhanced recommendation right.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The Supervisory Board spent considerable time discussing its future
	composition, in view of the rotation schedule and envisaged changes in 2015 and subsequent years. For the fulfillment of vacancies several factors are taken into consideration. The Supervisory Board profile includes the intention to have at least 30
	percent representation of each gender in ASML&#146;s Supervisory Board. This aspect has been taken into account in the process that has led to the nomination of the following three new Supervisory Board members to the 2015 AGM: Ms.&nbsp;A. (Annet)
	Aris, Mr.&nbsp;G.J. (Gerard) Kleisterlee and Mr.&nbsp;R.D. (Rolf-Dieter) Schwalb. The agenda and explanatory notes for the 2015 AGM will contain further information in this respect.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The Supervisory Board reappointed Mr.&nbsp;Schneider-Maunoury for another period of four years upon notification to the 2014 AGM. The indefinite appointment term of Mr.&nbsp;Wennink and Mr.&nbsp;Van den Brink was
	converted into a definite appointment term of four years per the 2014 AGM. Mr.&nbsp;Nickl was appointed as member of the BoM upon notification to the 2014 AGM.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	There are no family relationships among the members of our Supervisory Board and our BoM.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D737660D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents

</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Director and Officer Biographies
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Arthur P.M. van der Poel
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Mr.&nbsp;Van der Poel was appointed to our Supervisory Board in March 2004 and
	was appointed as Chairman in March 2007. Mr.&nbsp;Van der Poel was CEO of Philips Semiconductors, a member of the Board of Management and a member of the Group Management Committee of Royal Philips Electronics N.V. Currently, Mr.&nbsp;Van der Poel
	is a member of the Board of Directors of Gemalto Holding N.V. and the Chairman of the Supervisory Board of BDR Thermea. Mr.&nbsp;Van der Poel was a member of the Supervisory Board of Royal HaskoningDHV B.V. until April&nbsp;1, 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Fritz W. Fr&ouml;hlich
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Mr.&nbsp;Fr&ouml;hlich was
	appointed to our Supervisory Board in March 2004. Mr.&nbsp;Fr&ouml;hlich was Deputy Chairman and CFO of Akzo Nobel N.V. Currently, Mr.&nbsp;Fr&ouml;hlich is the Chairman of the Supervisory Board of Randstad Holding N.V., a member of the Supervisory
	Boards of Allianz Nederland N.V. and Rexel S.A. and a member of the Board of Directors of Prysmian Group.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Pauline F.M. van der Meer Mohr
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Ms.&nbsp;Van der Meer Mohr was appointed to our Supervisory Board in March 2009. Ms.&nbsp;Van der Meer Mohr was managing partner of the
	Amstelbridge Group, Senior Executive Vice President at ABN AMRO Bank, Head of Group Human Resources at TNT N.V., and has held several senior executive roles at the Royal/Dutch Shell group of companies in various areas. Currently, Ms.&nbsp;Van der
	Meer Mohr serves as President of the Executive Board of the Erasmus University Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Ms.&nbsp;Van der Meer Mohr is also a member of the Supervisory Board of Royal DSM N.V., the Chairperson of the Executive Board of the
	Fulbright Center and a member of the Board Concertgebouw Fonds. Ms.&nbsp;Van der Meer Mohr was the Chairperson of the Supervisory Board of Rotterdam School of Management until December&nbsp;1, 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Wolfgang H. Ziebart
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Mr.&nbsp;Ziebart was appointed
	to our Supervisory Board in March 2009. Mr.&nbsp;Ziebart was President and CEO of Infineon Technologies A.G. Prior to that, Mr.&nbsp;Ziebart was on the Boards of Management of car components manufacturer Continental A.G. and automobile producer BMW
	A.G. Currently, Mr.&nbsp;Ziebart is the Group Engineering Director of Jaguar Land Rover Ltd. and is the Chairman of the Supervisory Board of Nordex S.E.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Clara (Carla) M.S. Smits-Nusteling
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Ms.&nbsp;Smits-Nusteling was appointed to our Supervisory Board in April 2013. Ms.&nbsp;Smits-Nusteling was CFO and a member of the Board of Management of Royal KPN
	N.V. Ms.&nbsp;Smits-Nusteling also held several finance and business related positions at Royal KPN N.V. and PostNL. Currently, Ms.&nbsp;Smits-Nusteling is a non-executive director of the Board of Tele2 AB.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Douglas A. Grose
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Mr.&nbsp;Grose was appointed to our
	Supervisory Board in April 2013. Mr.&nbsp;Grose was CEO of GlobalFoundries. Mr.&nbsp;Grose also served as senior vice president of technology development, manufacturing and supply chain for AMD. Prior to that, Mr.&nbsp;Grose spent 25 years at IBM as
	General Manager of technology development and manufacturing for the systems and technology group. Currently, Mr.&nbsp;Grose is a member of the Board of Directors of SBA Materials.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Johannes (Hans) M.C. Stork
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Mr.&nbsp;Stork was appointed to our Supervisory Board in April 2014.
	Mr.&nbsp;Stork held various management positions at IBM Corporation, Hewlett Packard Company, Texas Instruments, Inc. and Applied Materials, Inc., including Senior Vice President and CTO of Texas Instruments, Inc. and Group Vice President and CTO of
	Applied Materials, Inc. Further, Mr.&nbsp;Stork was a member of the Board of Sematech. Currently, Mr.&nbsp;Stork serves as Senior Vice President and CTO of ON Semiconductor Corporation and is also a member of the Scientific Advisory Board of imec.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Peter T.F.M. Wennink
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Mr.&nbsp;Wennink
	joined ASML on January&nbsp;1, 1999 and was appointed as Executive Vice President, CFO and member of our BoM on July&nbsp;1, 1999. Mr.&nbsp;Wennink was appointed as President and CEO on July&nbsp;1, 2013. Mr.&nbsp;Wennink has an extensive background
	in finance and accounting. Prior to his employment with ASML, Mr.&nbsp;Wennink worked as a partner at Deloitte Accountants, specializing in the high technology industry with an emphasis on the semiconductor equipment industry. Mr.&nbsp;Wennink is a
	member of the Dutch Institute of Registered Accountants, a member of the Supervisory Board of Bank Insinger de Beaufort N.V. and a member of the Advisory Board of the Investment Committee of Stichting Pensioenfonds ABP (Dutch pension fund for
	government employees). Mr.&nbsp;Wennink further serves on the board of the FME-CWM (the employers&#146; organization for the technology industry in the Netherlands).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D737660D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Martin A. van den Brink
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Mr.&nbsp;Van den Brink joined ASML when the company was founded in 1984. Mr.&nbsp;Van den Brink held several positions in engineering and from 1995 he served as Vice President Technology. Mr.&nbsp;Van den Brink was
	appointed as Executive Vice President Product&nbsp;&amp; Technology and member of the BoM in 1999. On July&nbsp;1, 2013, Mr.&nbsp;Van den Brink was appointed as President and CTO. Mr.&nbsp;Van den Brink earned a degree in Electrical Engineering from
	HTS Arnhem (HAN University), and a degree in Physics (1984)&nbsp;from the University of Twente, the Netherlands. In 2012, he was awarded an honorary doctorate in physics by the UvA, the Netherlands.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Frits J. van Hout
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Mr.&nbsp;Van Hout joined ASML in
	1984 and rejoined ASML in 2001, after a nine years absence. He was appointed as a member of our BoM on March&nbsp;26, 2009. Mr.&nbsp;Van Hout was appointed as Executive Vice President and CPO on July&nbsp;1, 2013. Prior to that, Mr.&nbsp;Van Hout
	served as Executive Vice President and CMO, Executive Vice President Integral Efficiency, Senior Vice President Customer Support and held various other positions. From 1992 until 2001, Mr.&nbsp;Van Hout served as CEO of the Beyeler Group and held
	various management positions at Datacolor International. Mr.&nbsp;van Hout earned a Master&#146;s degree in Theoretical Physics (1981), University of Oxford; and a Master&#146;s degree in Applied Physics (1984), Eidgen&ouml;ssische Technische
	Hochschule, Z&uuml;rich.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Fr&eacute;d&eacute;ric J.M. Schneider-Maunoury
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Mr.&nbsp;Schneider-Maunoury joined ASML on December&nbsp;1, 2009, as Executive Vice President and COO and was appointed to our BoM on March&nbsp;24, 2010. Prior to joining ASML, Mr.&nbsp;Schneider-Maunoury served
	as Vice President Thermal Products Manufacturing of the power generation and rail transport equipment group ALSTOM. Previously, Mr. Schneider-Maunoury was general manager of the worldwide Hydro Business of ALSTOM. Further,
	Mr.&nbsp;Schneider-Maunoury held various positions at the French Ministry of Trade and Industry. Mr.&nbsp;Schneider-Maunoury is a graduate of Ecole Polytechnique (1985)&nbsp;and Ecole Nationale Sup&eacute;rieure des Mines (1988)&nbsp;in Paris.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Wolfgang U. Nickl
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Mr.&nbsp;Nickl joined
	ASML on December&nbsp;1, 2013, as Executive Vice President and CFO and was appointed as a member of our BoM per the 2014 AGM. Prior to joining ASML, Mr.&nbsp;Nickl served as Executive Vice President and CFO at Western Digital Corporation, a
	U.S.-headquartered, NASDAQ-listed developer and manufacturer of storage devices, where he held several financial and operational leadership roles. Before Western Digital, Mr.&nbsp;Nickl gained experience in finance and IT consulting. He earned a BA
	in Business from the University of Cooperative Education in Stuttgart, Germany, and an MBA from the University of Southern California&#146;s Marshall School of Business in Los Angeles, United States.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D737660D20F_HTM_TOC737660_26">
</A>
	B. Compensation
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	The information
	required by Item&nbsp;6.B. is incorporated by reference from our 2014 Remuneration Report (pages 14,15,16, 18 and 19) which is included as exhibit 99.2 on Form 6-K furnished with the SEC on February&nbsp;11, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D737660D20F_HTM_TOC737660_27">
</A>
	C. Board Practices
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="2">
<B>
	General
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	We endorse the importance of good corporate governance, of which independent supervision, accountability and transparency are the most significant
	elements. Within the framework of corporate governance, it is important that a relationship of trust exists between the BoM, the Supervisory Board, our employees and our shareholders.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	We pursue a policy of active communication with our shareholders. In addition to the exchange of ideas at the General Meeting of Shareholders, other important forms of communication are the publication of our
	annual and quarterly financial results as well as press releases and publications posted on our Website.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Our corporate governance structure is intended
	to:
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Provide shareholders with regular, reliable, relevant and transparent information regarding our activities, structure, financial condition and results of
	operations, performance and other information, including information on our social, ethical and environmental matters and policies;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Apply high-quality standards for disclosure, accounting and auditing; and
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	Apply stringent rules with regard to insider securities trading.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="31%">

<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	ASML ANNUAL REPORT 2014
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
	36
</FONT>
</TD>
